texts.shortText:
Small to medium sized prawn with robust body usually a green/brown colour. Walking legs and underside of body paler.

Front of carapace (hard upper shell) ‘tridentate’, meaning the longer rostrum in the middle has two side-teeth, and these are less than half the length of the rostrum. Chelae (pincers) equal in size and not conventionally chelate, but rather the thumb is almost absent, with finger bending back to meet it. First two pairs of walking legs with no spine at their bases.

Global: South Africa and Namibia.

Local/Regional: From the border of Namibia to Mossel Bay, subtidal to 10 m.

Very little is known regarding the biology. Similar to Upogebia africana, this species prefers sediment with a mud content between 5–11%. Occurs in habitats deeper than U. africana and Kraussilichirus kraussi, such as subtidal channels; completely absent intertidally. It is noted that U. capensis is absent from estuaries (though present in Langebaan Lagoon, which has higher salinity than is common) and mostly found on the open coast, as it lacks the ability to osmoregulate below a salinity of 15-18 parts per thousand (ppt). Species specific ecological studies on the burrow structure, mode of feeding, detailed sedimentary requirements or interactions with other species such as the Common sandprawn and Estuarine mudprawn are lacking.
Not specifically known for this species, but likely similar to that of U. africana, which filter-feeds by sitting in their burrow filtering water that is pumped in through the U-shaped burrow.

Not specifically known, but likely similar to U. africana with females producing 2–4 broods per year (mostly in Summer and Spring). As in other decapod crustaceans, females attach the spermatophore (passed from the male) to the ventral side of the pleon (hind body), where the eggs are fertilized as they get spawned and then attached to the pleopods underneath the tail. Known to produce small, but numerous eggs (often several 1000 per brood per female). Larvae are released into the water column where they have a planktonic larval phase before they settle in the sediment, creating their burrows.
Similar to the larger Coastal mudprawn, Upogebia africana, however the first two pairs of walking legs have a spine at the base, while it is absent in the U. africana.

Barnard, KH (1950). Descriptive Catalogue of South African Decapod Crustacea. Annals of the South African Museum, 38, 1–824.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 112).

Nel, P & Branch, GM (2013). Assessment of the abundance and distribution of burrowing sandprawns and mudprawns (Callichirus and Upogebia species) in Langebaan Lagoon, South Africa. African Journal of Marine Science, 35(2), 195-208.
